title: FTX Bahamas vs. John Jay Ray, Bankman-Fried pleads not guilty, DoJ seizes FTX assets

last_post.content:
FTX Bahamas vs. John Jay Ray, Bankman-Fried pleads not guilty, DoJ seizes FTX assets - by Amy Castor and David Gerard

https://amycastor.com/2023/01/04/ftx-bahamas-vs-john-jay-ray-bankman-fried-pleads-not-guilty-doj-seizes-ftx-assets/

In today’s episode: Sam Bankman-Fried pleads not guilty. If he doesn’t reach some sort of plea deal, then the trial’s scheduled for October.

But the real story is the shenanigans in the Bahamas, where the Securities Commission of the Bahamas and the Joint Provisional Liquidators seem to be positing FTX Digital Markets as the operating centre of FTX — when it was just a minor entity in one country.

John Jay Ray’s team has filed an incendiary motion objection detailing the shenanigans, and asking the judge to tell the Bahamas entities to just bugger off.

Also, the Department of Justice seized a pile of FTX Bahamas bank accounts and crypto assets — and SBF’s shares in Robinhood.

title: UC strike causes union organizing surge for academic workers

last_post.content:
Students and labor experts say the successful UC strike is influencing a wave of union organizing at higher-learning institutions across the country.

The UC strike drew national attention by marshaling four UAW bargaining units on all 10 campuses and the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory.

Now, graduate students at about a dozen schools are organizing unions and universities are offering raises to some academic workers as they try to remain competitive.

Read more at https://www.latimes.com/california/story/2023-01-02/uc-strike-energizes-labor-surge

Hi, I've just moved over to hcommons.social, so here's an #introduction. I work (and make things) at the nexus of digital culture, politics and technology. I'm Prof of Media at Coventry University, UK, where I direct the Centre for Postdigital Cultures. I research non-liberal & non-humanist forms of collaboration and knowledge commons, as well as questions of class, elitism & digital capitalism. I’ve been involved for a while in creating ‘norm-critical’ collaborative research contexts. In 1999 I started an online journal Culture Machine http://www.culturemachine.net/. In 2006 I co-founded the open access publishing house Open Humanities Press. OHP was then a founder member of the Radical Open Access Collective http://radicaloa.disruptivemedia.org.uk/. My books include A Stubborn Fury: How Writing Works In Elitist Britain (OHP, 2021) http://www.openhumanitiespress.org/books/titles/a-stubborn-fury/, Pirate Philosophy (MIT Press, 2016) https://mitpress.mit.edu/9780262034401/pirate-philosophy/, and The Uberfication of the University (Minnesota UP, 2016) https://manifold.umn.edu/projects/the-uberfication-of-the-university.

title: What in the Ethereum application ecosystem excites me

last_post.content:
"DAO's for inceased robustness" is one of the ideas in Vitalik's summary of #crypto applications: https://vitalik.eth.limo/general/2022/12/05/excited.html

Corporations are vulnerable hostile takeovers - Twitter for example. A DeFi app like Uniswap isn't vulnerable, as long as Ethereum itself stays neutral.

But a DAOs is more similar to corporation. The crypto model of "develop once, clone many times" actually is a form of federation. Maybe we should talk about the Uniswap & all its clones as a single federated organization?

title: Cycles PBR thin film interference, iridescence and metals

last_post.content:
I spoke at #BCon22 last year, introducing a way to #render #interference (aka #iridescence ) with #Blender3D and #cycles

Interference can occur when light passes thin layers, and it can radically change the color of the reflection. Possibly the best example is a soap bubble, but also heating of iron and aging of copper is described well by interference (see examples).

I made node groups with example materials available for #Blender, free to use for any purpose. See:

https://blenderartists.org/t/cycles-pbr-thin-film-interference-iridescence-and-metals/672094

last_post.content:
A toot from yesterday that lamented the need to wrangle with Vulkan extensions reminded me that I haven't plugged volk here yet!

If you use Vulkan in C/C++ (unless you use Vulkan-Hpp which I advise against), you should be using https://github.com/zeux/volk.

volk always supports the most recent Vulkan extensions (it is updated on the day new extensions get released), and it's just a couple lines to integrate. It also ships with Vulkan SDK these days!

title: Prestigious Science Journals Struggle to Reach Even Average Reliability

last_post.content:
@cboettig This is an excellent point. It probably depends a lot on who you ask at what stage which function of the literature they find most prominent.

Given how bad the current currency of "publishing in an exclusive journal" is (see, e.g.: https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fnhum.2018.00037/full ), it appears not very difficult to improve on it. For instance, one could start by counting not just the false-positives in such a selection process, but also the false-negatives:

title: Dark Alley – small god of Survived Hardships

last_post.content:
They say what doesn’t kill you makes you stronger, but that’s not always true. Sometimes what doesn’t kill you just makes you harder and more brittle, scarred and stiffened by the unwanted agonies of a world too big and too cruel for any single person to understand. Dark Alley understands that very well. Alley is the small god of the ones who survive. Not the ones who thrive, not the ones who pass unbroken, just the ones who somehow manage to keep standing.
